fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:description: A lossless compression algorithm for digital data of many kinds, named for the creators Abraham Lempel and Jacob Ziv, and a later contributor, Terry Welch. LZW is based on a translation table that maps strings of input characters into codes. Through its incorporation in the graphics file formats GIF_89a and TIFF_LZW, LZW has come to be strongly associated with image compression.
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:shortDescription: A lossless compression algorithm used most widely for bitmapped image data.
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:productionPhase: Used for initial-, middle- and final-state (end-user delivery) purposes.

fdd:relationship.fdd:comment: Other file or wrapper formats, not documented at this time

fdd:localUse.fdd:preference: TIFF_G4 (for images of documents) and TIFF_UNC (for documents or pictorial images) are preferred as master images. Future explorations may add J2K_C (JPEG 2000 Part 1, Core Coding System), especially J2K_L_LL (JPEG 2000 Part 1, Core Coding , Lossless Compression) to the Library's list of preferences.

fdd:disclosure.p: Proprietary standard ("open"). Predecessor algorithms were developed by Abraham Lempel and Jacob Ziv; LZW is the refined version finalized by Terry Welch, an employee of Sperry Corporation (later merged with Burroughs to form the Unisys Corporation).

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:documentation: The definitive descriptive article by Welch: "A Technique for High-Performance Data Compression." Patent 4,558,302 was granted in 1985; key in number at Patent Number Search at the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office.

fdd:adoption.p: Widely adopted. Many software tools exist for encoding and decoding. Generally not natively supported by Web browsers.

fdd:licensingAndPatents.p: LZW is notorious because of late-in-the-game patent-protection actions taken by Unisys beginning in late 1994, perceived as having an adverse affect on the Web due to that medium's widespread use of GIF images, which employ LZW compression. Unisys's US patent expired in June 2003, and its European and Japanese patents expired in June 2004. In 2007, the company's LZW Patent and Software Information Web page stated that the "Unisys Corporation holds and has patents pending on a number of improvements on the inventions claimed in the above-expired patents." As of January 2012, the Unisys Web site has no mention of LZW.

fdd:transparency.p: Relatively transparent but depends upon algorithms and tools to read.

fdd:stillImageQF.fdd:clarity: Excellent, given that LZW offers lossless compression.

fdd:notes.fdd:history: The ironically titled "Sad day . . . GIF patent dead at 20" includes a useful chronology compiled by an individual unhappy with Unisys's patent protections.

fdd:urlReference.comment: Also available from the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office search page [http://patft.uspto.gov/netahtml/PTO/srchnum.htm]: enter 4,558,302.

fdd:citation.fdd:articleReference: Welch, Terry A. "A Technique for High-Performance Data Compression", Computer, Vol. 17, No. 6 (June 1984): pp. 8-19. ISSN: 0018-9162. Doi: 10.1109/MC.1984.1659158. In addition to the version available to IEEE subscribers. Page images of this definitive article by Terry Welch, have also been made available online: as PNG images on a Russian site; and in a PDF.

fdd:urlReference.comment: By Mark Nelson. Corrected version of article that appeared in Dr. Dobbs Journal in October 1989.
By Mark Nelson. Update to article "LZW Data Compression," cited above.

fdd:urlGroup.fdd:intro: The Encyclopedia of Graphic File Formats, 2nd Edition, 1996 (EGFF) has information on LZW compression. Online access is available at:

fdd:urlReference.comment: From FileFormat.Info. This presentation states that the work has been released under a Creative Commons license.
From FileFormat.Info, via Internet Archive's Wayback Machine. Included because FileFormat.info has not been updated recently (as of November 2012) and was not functioning for a period.

fdd:urlGroup.fdd:intro: For historical purposes, information captured prior to 2010 by the Internet Archive from Unisys Web site may be of interest. Â As of 2012, Unisys no longer has information related to LZW or its related patents on its Web site.

fdd:urlReference.tag: Definitions of sites that qualified for Intranet/Billboard LZW license

fdd:urlGroup.fdd:intro: An article announcing the expiry of the LZW patent, 4558302, and providing a timeline for the "patent saga" appeared in June 2003 and was shared around the Web.

fdd:urlReference.comment: Web page regarding Unisys patent policy, 1994-2003

fdd:citation.fdd:articleReference: Ziv J., Lempel A., "A Universal Algorithm for Sequential Data Compression", IEEE Transactions on Information Theory, Vol. 23, No. 3, (1977): pp. 337-343. ISSN: 0018-9448. From Citeseer at http://citeseer.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.118.8921&rep=rep1&type=pdf. Also at http://www.ece.gatech.edu/users/swm/0337ziv.pdf

Ziv J., Lempel A., "Compression of Individual Sequences via Variable-Rate Coding", IEEE Transactions on Information Theory, Vol. 24, No. 5, (1978): pp. 530-536. ISSN: 0018-9448. From Citeseer at http://citeseer.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.14.2892&rep=rep1&type=pdf. Also at http://www.cs.duke.edu/courses/spring03/cps296.5/papers/ziv_lempel_1978_variable-rate.pdf.

fdd:citation.fdd:bookReference: Murray, James D. and William vanRyper. Encyclopedia of Graphics File Formats, 2nd Edition. Sebastopol, CA. : O'Reilly & Associates, 1996. Includes CD-ROM with complete text of book, and copies of several file format specifications.
